lines.text: [last lines]
Susan.
What?
What else did you ask Mr. Kringle for?
A baby brother. See ya.
You think I'm a fraud, don't you?
Fraud is a bit too strong of a word.
But you don't believe in me.
I believe that Christmas is for children.
Well your daughter doesn't believe in me, either.
I don't think that there's any harm in not believing in a figure that many do acknowledge to be a fiction.

Oh, but there is. I'm not just a whimsical figure who wears a charming suit and affects a jolly demeanor. You know, I I I'm a symbol. I'm a symbol of the human ability to be able to suppress the selfish and hateful tendencies that rule the major part of our lives. If you can't believe, if you can't accept anything on faith, then you're doomed for a life dominated by doubt.
A lie that draws a smile or a truth that draws a tear.
[Bryan and Dorey are at the altar]
Are you ready?
For what?
To get married.
Susan, there is something I have to tell you.
Merry Christmas.
I don't care what you asked Mr. Kringle for. Susan, that is not why we're going to the house.
We're going to the cataloged house, right? That's the house I told him I wanted. I showed him a picture of it and he took it and he said he would get for me.
Well, a house is a pretty big gift, Susan.
That's what Mr. Kringle said.

Honey, we are going to the house because it snowed. And it's very pretty. And because Mr. Shellhamer wants to take photographs for next years Christmas catalog. Which, I think, is awfully bold of him. It is a holiday.
That's just an excuse. Mr. Kringle did all this. I'm very sorry Mother, you have it perfectly wrong.
This is the house I asked Kris for, and he got me a dad, and the third thing I'll just have to wait for.

Would it please the court if I gave you your Christmas card? I don't think I'll see you again. Unless I get arrested which is highly unlikely because it's Christmas Eve and I'm going to bed uncharacteristically early.
Mr. Collins, would you like to cross examine
[quietly chuckles]
your wife?

[pointing toward Ed Collins]
Well, tell me something, Daniel could that man be Santa Claus?
Nope.
Why not?
'Cause Santa don't got a grumpy face.
[first lines]
Ask him. Ask him. Look at him, Grandpa. Ask him.
Uh, I'm sorry. He, uh he thinks you're Santa Claus.
[Kris Kringle and Judge Harper laugh]

[quietly to Harper's grandson]
I am.
[to Harper]
Merry Christmas.
Are you still coming to dinner?
Am I still invited?
Would you be our Santa Claus?
Uh, me?
Well, do you have any experience?
Well just a little.
Well, I would greatly like to oblige, Mr. Collins, but I cannot make this reindeer fly.
I didn't think so.
He only flies on Christmas Eve.
Mr. Collins, I hope you've taken down that old TV antenna. I ripped my pants on it last year.
[Judge Harper's grandson realizes that he had just met Kris Kringle]
Nuts. I should have got his autograph.
[to Judge Harper, after testifying in court]
Do I have to go to jail now?
This guy ain't dangerous. He may be off his rails a bit, but he ain't nothing. And if he wants to call himself Santa Claus, then God bless him.
Do you believe in Santa Claus?
I can't sleep.
What's on your mind?
Santa Claus.
Mr. Kringle? What about him?
He talked sign language with a kid today.
That was considerate of him.
He looks like every picture of Santa Claus I've ever seen.
I know. That's why I hired him.
Hi Judge, how is the grandson of yours?
[Harper gets shocked]
The parade? He thought I looked like Santa Claus.
Oh yeah.
Do you swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth?
Yes, but don't I put my hand on a Bible?
No, sir, you don't.
Well, I'll put my hand on my heart instead. I do.
